bibl.title: William W. Tinkham v. Jasper Gates. Petition for Writ
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: Third Judicial District of Washington Territory, holding Terms at Seattle

body.p: Territory of Washington ] County of King] ss.
To the Hon. Richard A. Jones, Chief Justice of Washington Territory, and Judge of the Third Judicial District thereof.
The petition of William W. Tinkham respectfully shows:

I. That William W. Tinkham is unlawfully imprisoned, detained, confined and restrained of his liberty by Jasper Gates, Deputy Constable for Mount Vernon Precinct Skagit County, Washington Territory, at the City of Seattle, King County, Washington Territory.

II. That according to the best of the knowledg and belief of this applicant the cause or pretense of his restraint is that on the 31st day of August, 1887, this applicant complained to John T. Mason, a Justice of the Peace in and for Mount Vernon Precinct, Skagit County, Washington Territory, of David E. Kimble and A.B. Corriell, charging them with threatening to strike, beat and kill your applicant and Annie L. Tinkham, and said Justice of the Peace did on the 2nd day of September, 1887 after hearing said cause, decided that the said charge of the said William W. Tinkham, your applicant, was unfounded and fivolous, and ordered that your applicant pay the costs of the prosecution, taxed at $40.25, and that he stand committed until said costs are paid, and ordered that the said Deputy Constable, Jasper Gates, commit your applicant

III. That the said imprisonment, detention, confinement and restraint are illegal, and the illegality consists to this, to-wit: [1] that the said Justice of the Peace had no jurisdiction to enter any judgement against your petitioner for costs in said action: [2] that said Justice of the Peace had no jurisdiction to enter an order committing your petitioner; [3] that said Justice of the Peace had no jurisdiction to issue a commitment against your petitioner in said matter; [4] that said commitment is without authority of law, and is void; [5] that the said costs amounting to $40.25, for which your petitioner is committed is in excess of what should have been taxed in said matter; [6] that the legal costs of said matter should not exceed the sume of $7.65

WHEREFORE your petitioner prays that a writ of HABEAS CORPUS may be granted directed to the said Jasper Gates, commanding him to have the body of William W. Tinkham before your Honor at a time and place therein to be specified, to do and receive what shall then and there be considered by your Honor concerning him, together with the time and cause of his detention, and said writ; and that he may be restored to his liberty.
Dated on the 14th day of September, 1887.
Burke + Haller Attorneys for Applicant
Territory of Washington } ss County of King

William W. Tinkham being first duly sworn, on oath says: That he is the petitioner in the foregoing petition in the above entitled action that he has heard the foregoing petiton read, knows the contents thereof, and believes the same to be true;
William W. Tinkham
Subscribed and Sworn to before me this 14th day of September 1887
B.J. Tallinan Notary Public in and for King County Washington Territory
In the District Court, Third Judicial District, holding terms at Seattle, King County
In the matter of the application of William W. Tinkham for a Writ of Habeas Corpus
Petition
FILED SEP 14 1887 W.E. Ledgerwood, Clerk.
BURKE & HALLER. Attorneys for
